awd_titl_txt: Stochastic Constitutive Models for Nano-Scale Heat Transport
awd_abstract_narration:
At the nano-mechanical scale, heat conduction processes exhibit a wide variety of phenomena that are different from macroscopic observations.  Conventional models, such as the Fourier's law,  are inadequate. In addition, there are overwhelming observations that suggest that heat conduction properties depend critically on the system size and geometry, creating a unique challenge for the portability of the mathematical models. This project aims to bridge the modeling gap by developing a first-principle based approach that leads to a hierarchy of generalized models. The new models have the potential capabilities to describe various important behavior of heat conduction processes, including the wave propagation characteristic, fluctuation, delay, and more. 

The proposed approach will derive new constitutive models from first-principle, and mathematically, the models are obtained from a microscopic many-particle description with three levels of reductions: A spatial reduction that eliminates atomic-level details and singles out the dynamics of the average energy, a temporal reduction that removes the nonlocality in time, and a statistical reduction that efficiently samples scale-dependent, statistical noises. Such a first-principle based approach derives its benefit from its combination of mathematical transparency, robustness, and amenability to error estimates. Unlike conventional theories, the current approach yields a stochastic constitutive model. Combined with energy balance, the constitutive models lead to stochastic partial differential equations, for which there is a wealth of interesting mathematical and computational issues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has been motivated by recent advances in nanoscale materials with unusual mechanical and electrical properties. This project took a first-principle approach that starts at the electronic and atomic level, where the system under consideration is either described by a quantum mechanical or an atomistic model governed by fundamental physical laws. The goal of the project is to determine a constitutive relation that takes into account the microstructures, electronic properties, and stochastic noise.

The project laid fundamental groundworks by developing a rigorous mathematical framework for deriving general constitutive relations. These results, including a hierarchy of stochastic models, have been published in applied mathematics journals (one in Communications in Mathematical Sciences and another in SIAM Journal of Multiscale Modeling and Simulations).

The PI’s team also developed efficient algorithms. These algorithms have been shown to be much more efficient than direct simulation methods. To make impacts on broader areas, these results have been  published in leading journals in chemistry (Journal of Chemical Physics and Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation).

The project  placed an emphasis on data driven methods, where the parameters in the constitutive relation can be inferred from data. Statistical and approximation errors have been analyzed. These results have been published in data science related journals.

Graduate students have been supported by this NSF fund. Two of them have graduated and continued their academic career. This grant also supported undergraduate students for their summer research.
